metadata./Title: Painless esophageal rupture in the second stage of labor presenting as surgical emphysema of the neck: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Pneumomediastinum in pregnancy has been described in around 200 cases, with an incidence 
of 1:100,000 pregnancies. The etiology is presumed to be either alveolar barotrauma secondary to the Valsalva 
maneuver (Hamman’s syndrome) during the second stage of labor, or spontaneous esophageal rupture (Boerhaave’s 
syndrome). The latter has a much higher morbidity/mortality and classically arises from esophageal rupture dur ing excessive vomiting. Boerhaave’s syndrome is described as a triad of chest pain, vomiting, and surgical emphysema, though all symptoms are seen in only one-third of cases. The majority of reported obstetric cases originate 
from vomiting in early pregnancy with patients clinically unwell, presenting with acute severe chest pain and short ness of breath.
sections.Case Presentation: Case presentation We present a case of esophageal rupture in a 24-year-old Eastern European primigravida, pre senting postnatally with neck emphysema in the absence of significant chest pain or other symptoms.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion The diagnosis of Boerhaave’s syndrome is often delayed, and a high index of clinical suspicion is required 
to reach a timely diagnosis.

sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Pneumomediastinum in pregnancy has been described 
in around 200 cases, with an incidence of 1:100,000 preg nancies [1]. The etiology is presumed to be either alveolar 
barotrauma secondary to the Valsalva maneuver (Ham man’s syndrome) during the second stage of labor, or spontaneous esophageal rupture (Boerhaave’s syndrome) 
[1–3]. The latter has a much higher morbidity/mortal ity and classically arises from esophageal rupture during 
excessive vomiting. Boerhaave’s syndrome is described 
as a triad of chest pain, vomiting, and surgical emphy sema, though all symptoms are seen in only one-third 
of cases [4, 5]. The majority of reported obstetric cases 
originate from vomiting in early pregnancy with patients 
clinically unwell, presenting with acute severe chest pain 
and shortness of breath. In the present work, we report 
an unusual presentation of Boerhaave’s syndrome, mani festing intrapartum, which was successfully managed 
conservatively.Open Access

Case presentation
A 24-year-old Eastern European primigravida pre sented at 38 + 6  weeks gestation for induction of labor. 
Her antenatal course was uncomplicated. Induction was 
performed using a cervical ripening balloon followed by 
prostaglandin pessary. Spontaneous rupture of mem branes (SROM) occurred 7.5  hours after insertion of 
pessary.
Cervical dilatation progressed from 3 cm to 10 cm over 
the next 4.5  hours. Oxytocin augmentation was com menced in the second stage owing to inadequate con tractions. She was administered an antiemetic after an 
episode of vomiting. Delivery was by ventouse and sub sequent forceps after 80 minutes of active second stage. 
A postpartum hemorrhage of 1.7  L was controlled with 
syntometrine, oxytocin infusion, and tranexamic acid.
Intravenous antibiotics were commenced 4 hours post partum for pyrexia and tachycardia. She remained stable 
and was transferred to the postnatal ward. The following 
morning, she complained of mild discomfort in her chest, 
neck, and face. Subcutaneous emphysema was palpable 
in these areas. She remained stable with mild tachycar dia, tachypnea, and with oxygen saturations of 99% on 
room air. Chest radiograph was unremarkable apart from 
visible subcutaneous emphysema.
A referral was made to general surgical, medical, and 
obstetric-medicine teams, with a plan made for contrast 
computerized tomographic (CT) imaging of the chest. 
The radiological report was of extensive pneumomedi astinum and surgical emphysema tracking into the neck 
and anterior chest wall, with no convincing features to 
suggest a tracheobronchial or esophageal perforation. 
The presumed diagnosis was therefore alveolar baro trauma (Hamman’s syndrome). She remained stable and 
was kept nothing-by-mouth with supportive treatment 
of intravenous fluids/antibiotics for 48  hours. She was 
transfused two units of blood as her hemoglobin was 
67 g/dL (119 g/dL predelivery).
Opinion was sought from regional cardiothoracic and 
upper gastrointestinal surgeons, who advised CT oral 
contrast with Gastrografin (Fig.  1). This was performed 
the next day and identified an anterior esophageal tear 
just superior to the tracheobronchial carina. The pre sumed etiology was spontaneous esophageal rupture 
(Boorhave’s syndrome) from either vomiting or exces sive Valsalva maneuver during the active second stage. 
Unusually, she was medically stable and denied any sig nificant symptoms apart from mild discomfort from the 
surgical emphysema.
She reported being entirely pain-free by day 2, and the 
palpable crepitus on her neck and upper chest resolved 
by day 3. She continued to improve, was started on soft 
diet on day 4, and was subsequently discharged home. While no formal follow-up was implemented, the patient 
conceived later the same year and was reviewed by the 
maternal medicine team. Her antenatal course and deliv ery were uncomplicated, and she underwent an uncom plicated elective cesarean section in February 2024, 
13 months after her esophageal perforation.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
We report this case of spontaneous esophageal rupture in 
labor to raise awareness of an uncommon presentation of 
this rare condition. Most reported cases of pneumomedi astinum in pregnancy are benign and self-limiting, with 
the diagnostic priority being to rule out esophageal per foration, which is absent in most cases [1]. Where esoph ageal perforation has occurred, most case studies report 
an acutely unwell patient with chest pain and shortness 
of breath. Differential diagnoses include pulmonary 
embolism, myocardial infarction, or pneumonia [5].
In this case, the patient described nonspecific symp toms of neck swelling and a crackling sensation on palpa tion. She denied any significant chest pain or shortness of 
breath and was clinically well throughout. In one study, 
97% of patients with esophageal rupture had an abnormal 
chest radiograph, which was normal in our patient [6]. 
Initial CT of the thorax demonstrated extensive pneumo mediastinum and chest wall surgical emphysema, with 
no convincing features to suggest esophageal perfora tion. She was therefore initially managed in conjunction

with the medical team for suspected Hamman’s syn drome. Following surgical input, CT with oral Gastro grafin was performed and identified an esophageal tear. 
The etiology of spontaneous esophageal rupture in labor 
is unclear. There is only one case report of obstetric spon taneous esophageal rupture in the absence of vomiting. 
Several studies suggest an association between long labor 
and surgical emphysema [7], though this is contested by 
others [8]. Prompt diagnosis is important to minimize 
leakage into the mediastinum and should not be delayed 
by the absence of classical symptoms or appearance on 
imaging without oral contrast.
In most reported obstetric cases, endoscopy is not 
recommended [9], and conservative rather than surgical 
management is appropriate [10]. Conservative manage ment consists of avoidance of oral intake, implementa tion of parenteral nutrition, intravenous antibiotics for 
7 days, and drainage of possible fluid collections. In cases 
of clinical deterioration, surgical management may be 
subsequently indicated. Overall success of conservative 
management heavily relies upon prompt recognition, 
patient clinical picture, and causation [11].
Conclusion
The diagnosis of Boerhaave’s syndrome is often delayed, 
and a high index of clinical suspicion is required to reach 
a timely diagnosis.
